docs.snippet: Federal rules that take effect today require television stations to broadcast at least three hours a week of educational shows for children.    Still, the new rules have not put an end to the debate over programming for the young....
docs.abstract: Federal rules that take effect on Sept 1 require television stations to broadcast at least three hours a week of educational shows for children; new rules have not put an end to debate over programming for the young (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal rules that take effect today require television stations to broadcast at least three hours a week of educational shows for children. Still, the new rules have not put an end to the debate over programming for the young.

headline.main: Broadcasters Must Have Educational Programs For Children by Today

docs.snippet: LEAD: Seeq Technology Inc., a semiconductor company, said it would stop manufacturing its own computer chips and would instead have them manufactured by other companies. The move will mean the dismissal of about 95 workers, about a fifth of the co...

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Seeq Technology Inc., a semiconductor company, said it would stop manufacturing its own computer chips and would instead have them manufactured by other companies. The move will mean the dismissal of about 95 workers, about a fifth of the company's work force, and a one-time charge of $8 million to $10 million in the fourth quarter, which ends this month.

docs.snippet: To meet Boston's technology elite, first finagle an invitation to one of Robert M. Metcalfe's parties. His salons, as Mr. Metcalfe -- co-inventor of the computer technology named Ethernet -- calls them, are high-technology schmooze sessions, with ...
docs.abstract: Boston, fueled by talent pool from Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has become center for publications about technology and business; MIT's Technology Review, which switched to more upbeat coverage of innovation in technology, science and business under new publisher, R Bruce Journey, cited; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: To meet Boston's technology elite, first finagle an invitation to one of Robert M. Metcalfe's parties. His salons, as Mr. Metcalfe -- co-inventor of the computer technology named Ethernet -- calls them, are high-technology schmooze sessions, with perhaps a string of investors chatting up a chief executive in the hallway or two entrepreneurs courting a partnership at dinner. But who invited the journalists? On a given night at Mr. Metcalfe's Back Bay home, it is not surprising to find a representative from the publications of International Data Group in one corner, an editor of Fast Company in another and staff members from M.I.T.'s Technology Review mingling among the suits.

headline.main: M.I.T. and Harvard Give Boston a Niche

docs.snippet: Integrated Device Technology Inc. agreed on Thursday to sell its microprocessor unit to Via Technology Inc., the computer chip-set maker based in Taiwan, for $51 million. IDT, which is based in Santa Clara, said the sale would allow it to focus on...
docs.abstract: Integrated Device Technology Inc sells its microprocessor unit to Via Technology Inc for $51 million (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Integrated Device Technology Inc. agreed on Thursday to sell its microprocessor unit to Via Technology Inc., the computer chip-set maker based in Taiwan, for $51 million. IDT, which is based in Santa Clara, said the sale would allow it to focus on products for the communications industry and exit a business that has been hurt by stiff price competition.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    You miss an important point as to why it is essential to make science seem like fun (''Bah! Who Says Science Must Seem Like Fun?'' Science Times, May 13). Although most of today's great scientific work will be done by those who a...
docs.abstract: Melvyn Jay Oremland letter disputes May 13 Science Times article on making science fun (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You miss an important point as to why it is essential to make science seem like fun (''Bah! Who Says Science Must Seem Like Fun?'' Science Times, May 13). Although most of today's great scientific work will be done by those who are really devoted to science and enjoy what they do, in order for our scientific and technological society to continue, it is absolutely necessary that the general public has some understanding of what is being done and where its research dollars are going.

headline.main: Making Science Fun Helps It Get Funds

docs.snippet: IT is a tribute to the power and precision of science that it was able to predict so far in advance that on April 1, Comet Hale-Bopp would make its closest rendezvous with the Sun. But what science could not reliably say was whether, in any partic...
docs.abstract: Scientists are still puzzling over what precisely is meant by complexity; at issue: how can essence of complexity be captured and quantified in precise definition that scientists can use? challenge of defining complexity has been compared to that confronting early 19th-century scientists as they tried to get grip on mysterious concept called energy; problem is that there is no way to know whether complexity will turn out to be something like energy, which can be precisely metered, or something like, say, prudence or charity, which will remain forever in realm of the subjective (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is a tribute to the power and precision of science that it was able to predict so far in advance that on April 1, Comet Hale-Bopp would make its closest rendezvous with the Sun. But what science could not reliably say was whether, in any particular part of the country, clouds would congeal to block the view -- a cosmic April Fool's joke. Some of the grandest phenomena, like the coursing of comets around the Sun, are marvelously predictable. But some of the most mundane, like weather, are so convoluted that they continue to elude the most diligent forecasters. They are what scientists call complex systems. Though made up of relatively simple units -- like the molecules in the atmosphere -- the pieces interact to yield behavior that is full of surprise.

headline.main: Researchers on Complexity Ponder What It's All About

docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich versus Al Gore: warriors in cyberspace?    Look for some big new battles on the electronic frontier this year as Newt Gingrich and his Republican followers in Congress face off against the Clinton Administration over Government polic...
docs.lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich versus Al Gore: warriors in cyberspace? Look for some big new battles on the electronic frontier this year as Newt Gingrich and his Republican followers in Congress face off against the Clinton Administration over Government policies to promote new technology.

headline.main: Congress and White House Split on High Tech
